speaker: Sam
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Sam.

speaker: Neil
text: And I'm Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: It's nice to see you, Neil, [smiley face], [high five], [fist bump]!

speaker: Neil
text: What's this, Sam? Are you saying hello with… emojis?!

speaker: Sam
text: Yes, I am! In this programme, we're entering the world of emojis - the small characters people use to show emotions in texts and emails. Do you have a favourite emoji, Neil? Mine's the [crying tears of laughter] emoji.

speaker: Neil
text: I like the [smiling face with hearts] one, and with over three thousand emojis to choose from, there's one for every occasion. It's one of the reasons why emojis have become so popular over the last 20 years - they let people put back some of the human emotion that's missing in written texts and emails.

speaker: Sam
text: We'll be finding out more about emojis, and learning some related vocabulary, soon… but first I have a question for you, Neil. It's about the word 'emoji' itself, which was invented in 1999 in Japan for the first internet-enabled mobile phones. The name, 'emoji', comes from the combination two Japanese words, but which words? Is the word 'emoji' a combination of:

speaker: Sam
text: a) face and emotion?

speaker: Sam
text: b) picture and character? or

speaker: Sam
text: c) message and image?

speaker: Neil
text: I'll say it's a) face and emotion.

speaker: Sam
text: OK, Neil. We'll find out if your answer gets a [thumbs up] at the end of the programme. When we talk with someone face to face, we use physical gestures like smiling, laughing or nodding to show the other person how we feel. But these gestures get lost in written communication.

speaker: Neil
text: That's where emojis come in - they add feeling and emotion to online messages. But not everyone is an emoji fan. Some people believe that carefully chosen words are the best way of expressing yourself, and that emojis are affecting our ability to put feelings into words.

speaker: Sam
text: Here's cognitive linguist, Professor Vyv Evans, author of a book about the language of emojis, explaining more to BBC Radio 4's, Word of Mouth.

speaker: the grammar police jaundiced the dark ages
text: A lot of people, you know, language-mavens, the grammar police and so on, or say… have this sort of jaundiced, prejudiced view about emoji - that it's taking us back to the dark ages of illiteracy - bring back Shakespeare, and stick to the language of Shakespeare and all the rest of it.

speaker: the grammar police jaundiced the dark ages
text: But that fundamentally misunderstands the nature of communication. Emoji is important. In fact, it makes us more effective communicators in the digital age.

speaker: the grammar police The grammar police
text: Vyv Evans describes people who don't approve of emojis as the grammar police - a slang term referring to people who want to see formal language and grammar - what they call 'correct' English - written online. The grammar police criticise modern styles of English and like to correct other people's mistakes in spelling and grammar.

speaker: the grammar police jaundiced
text: According to Professor Evans, the grammar police have a jaundiced view of emojis - they only see the negative side of them because of their own ideas and experiences.

speaker: the dark ages the dark ages
text: What's more, they think emojis are taking us back to the dark ages of illiteracy, when most people couldn't read or write. If someone refers to the dark ages, they mean a past time in history considered uncivilised, and characterised by ignorance.

speaker: Sam
text: But luckily for emoji fans, the grammar police are in the minority. Over 6 billion emoji messages are sent around the world every day, with about 70 percent containing emotion-based characters like [smiley face] and [blowing kisses].

speaker: Neil
text: According to Professor Evans, emoji users are more expressive, more effective communicators. So, could that be an advantage for someone looking for love online? That's what Michael Rosen, presenter of BBC Radio 4's, Word of Mouth, wanted to find out.

speaker: Michael Rosen
text: Is it possible to start a relationship using emoji?

speaker: dating lucky in lovedating
text: Well, there is research that's been conducted by Match.com, the American-based dating site, and what they've found, based on their research, is that the people that use more emojis tend to be lucky in love, they have more success in terms of dating. In the digital age, using emoji makes us more effective communicators…

speaker: Michael Rosen
text: … more expressive …

speaker: it stands to reason
text: … more expressive, we're better able to express our emotional selves, and people therefore it stands to reason, if you use more emojis you're gonna get more dates!

speaker: dating lucky in love
text: For people who are dating, or starting a romantic relationship with someone, it seems that using emojis helps them be lucky in love, an expression meaning lucky in finding a romantic partner.

speaker: it stands to reason
text: Emojis let us show our true personality, so, Professor Evans says, it stands to reason - in other words, it seems likely to be true - that emoji users get more dates.

speaker: it stands to reason
text: And that's a big [thumbs up] from me! What about your question, Sam? Did my answer get a [thumbs up] too?

speaker: Sam
text: In my question, I asked you which words combine to make up the Japanese word, 'emoji'.

speaker: Neil
text: I guessed it was a) face and emotion.

speaker: Sam
text: Which was [sad face] the wrong answer, I'm afraid. In fact, 'emoji' combines the words for 'picture' and 'character' in Japanese.

speaker: the grammar police
text: OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learnt about emojis, starting with the grammar police, people who want correct spelling and grammar online, and criticise those who don't.

speaker: jaundiced
text: If you have a jaundiced view of something, you only see the negative side because of your own bad experience with it.

speaker: The dark ages
text: 'The dark ages' describes a period in history characterised by ignorance and a lack of progress.

speaker: dating lucky in love
text: If you are dating someone, you are spending time with them romantically, which means you are lucky in love, an expression meaning lucky in finding a romantic partner.

speaker: it stands to reason
text: And finally, the phrase it stands to reason means that something seems likely to be true, or it makes sense. Once again, our six minutes are up. Bye for now!

speaker: Neil
text: Bye!
